subject: Critical Thinking
title: Fallacy Detection: A Practical Toolkit
description: A micro-lesson that makes Fallacy Detection: A Practical Toolkit usable.

hook.text: You don't need to memorize 100 Latin names. Three questions catch 90% of fallacies in real conversations.

buildup.text: Question 1: 'Does this evidence actually support this specific conclusion?' This catches irrelevance fallacies.

discovery.text: Question 2: 'What's being assumed but not stated?' This catches hidden premises, loaded questions, & circular reasoning.

twist.text: Question 3: 'What would change my mind?' If nothing could, your position is unfalsifiable ‚Äì & you might be the fallacy.

climax.text: Apply these three questions to your own arguments first. Self-testing is more valuable than catching others' errors.

punchline.text: Three questions. Most fallacies detected. No Latin required.

quiz.question: Which question helps catch hidden assumptions in arguments?
